items.dek: With more than 130,000 bottles of wine in the cellar *and* Mexican Coke, it’s a tough call on what to order to drink at [Restaurant Latour](http://www.crystalgolfresort.com/dine/latour/)—but we’re here for cocktails. Mixologist Stephen Thomas’s creation, the Straight Spring Truffle, isn’t even recognizable as a cocktail from above—it looks more like an artful paperweight or floral snow globe. You probably don’t have truffle vermouth lying around the house, but if you do, feel free to re-create this at your next dinner party to show off to your guests, which we have a feeling you might be used to doing.

items.hed: “There but for the Grace of God”
items.dek: Barack Obama became the first sitting U.S. president to visit a federal prison, and he realized that he could very well have ended up behind bars, were it not for his family and education.
Director Peyton Reed offers VF.com a glimpse into the creation of the movie—and its most impressive effect.

items.hed: An Unnecessarily Decadent Truffle Martini (Why Not?)
items.body:
With more than 135,000 bottles of wine in the cellar *and* Mexican Coke, it’s a tough call on what to order to drink at [Restaurant Latour](http://www.crystalgolfresort.com/dine/latour/), tucked away in Sussex County, New Jersey. 

Some people visit to golf at Crystal Springs Resort, others come for the spa, many stop by for extravagant tasting menus—but we’re here for cocktails. The resort mixologist and restaurant manager Stephen Thomas has put together a menu of cocktails as picturesque as the view from the floor-to-ceiling windows, showcasing local distilleries from Brooklyn, the Catskills, Hudson Valley, and yes, New Jersey. 

His creation, the Straight Spring Truffle, isn’t even recognizable as a cocktail from above—it looks more like an artful paperweight or floral snow globe. Truffle pearls and infused vermouth create a savory, luxurious drink that appeals to the dirty martini lover. You probably don’t have truffle vermouth lying around the house, but if you do—wow—feel free to re-create this at your next dinner party to show off to your guests, which we have a feeling you might be used to doing. 


[#image: /photos/55a909819e9755183d973b56]||||||





__Straight Spring Truffle__


3 oz [Catskill Mountain Distilling Peace Vodka](http://catskilldistillingcompany.com/)

1 oz house-made burgundy-truffle vermouth

10 truffle pearls (garnish)

In mixing glass, add vodka, vermouth, and ice. Stir until lightly chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with the truffle pearls and dill blossoms.
items.seoTitle: An Unnecessarily Decadent Truffle Martini (Why Not?)
items.seoDescription: Too much of a good thing can be wonderful—and drinkable.
items.socialTitle: An Unnecessarily Decadent Truffle Martini (Why Not?)
items.socialDescription: Too much of a good thing can be wonderful—and drinkable.

fields.name: Alex Beggs
fields.bio: Alex Beggs is an Associate Editor and Senior Rosé Correspondent at VanityFair.com.

items.hed: *The Revenant* Trailer: It’s Leonardo DiCaprio and His Beard Against the World
items.dek: You might need to lie down after watching this one.
items.body:
[#video: //www.youtube.com/embed/QRfj1VCg16Y](640x360)||||||





Take the fluid camera, pounding score, and general intensity of *Birdman*, and put it in the middle of a bunch of battles and some of the most gorgeous scenery you’ll ever see. That, apparently, is what we should all brace for in *The Revenant*, __Alejandro González Iñárritu’s__ follow-up to his best picture winner which is also the reason __Leonardo DiCaprio__ was [sporting that huge beard for so long]( http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/01/dicaprio-photos-the-revenant).  

The film is billed as a survival story, with DiCaprio and __Tom Hardy__ playing explorers stuck in the American wilderness of the 1860s, constantly tested by animals, native tribes, the harsh terrain, and each other. Remember how *The Revenant*’s cinematographer __Emmanuel Lubezki__ made us all so terrified of space with *Gravity*? This might do the same for the national parks system. 

*The Revenant* comes to theaters on December 25, which means, yes, the Oscar buzz begins now.
items.seoTitle: The Revenant Trailer Features Leonardo DiCaprio Going to Battle
items.socialTitle: The Revenant Trailer: It’s Leonardo DiCaprio and His Beard Against the World
items.socialDescription: You might need to lie down after watching this one.

items.hed: Obama on His Historic Visit to Federal Prison: “There but for the Grace of God”
items.dek: The trip hoped to bring publicity to a bipartisan effort to overhaul a prison system bloated by poor drug laws and wasting $80 billion a year.
items.seoTitle: Obama on His Historic Visit to Federal Prison: “There but for the Grac
items.seoDescription: The trip hoped to bring publicity to a bipartisan effort to overhaul a prison system bloated by poor drug laws and wasting $80 billion a year.
items.socialTitle: Obama after Historic Prison Visit: I Could Have Ended Up in Here
items.socialDescription: The trip hoped to bring publicity to a bipartisan effort to overhaul a prison system bloated by poor drug laws and wasting $80 billion a year.
items.body:
On Thursday, __Barack Obama__ became the first sitting president to visit a federal prison, and upon meeting several low-level, nonviolent drug offenders serving long sentences, reflected on the simple but crucial things that kept himself out of prison: a strong family structure and access to education.
 
During his visit to the El Reno correctional facility in Oklahoma, which he hoped would highlight the massive overhaul needed in America’s prison system and drug laws, Obama had the chance to sit down with six inmates, all serving time for nonviolent drug charges. [According to *The New York Times*,](http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/17/us/obama-el-reno-oklahoma-prison.html?_r=0) which—along with Vice—accompanied him on his visit, Obama realized that had it not been for the privileges granted to him, he could have ended up in prison due to his past minor drug use as a teenager, well documented in his memoir, *Dreams from My Father.*
 
 “There but for the grace of God,” he said. “And that, I think, is something that we all have to think about.”
 
Emphasizing that he had no “tolerance” for violent offenders—“Many of them may have made mistakes, but we need to keep our communities safe”—Obama nevertheless said that the stories of the six men with whom he met hit close to home. [Via the *Times*](http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/17/us/obama-el-reno-oklahoma-prison.html?_r=0):
 
>“When they describe their youth and their childhood, these are young people who made mistakes that aren’t that different than the mistakes I made and the mistakes that a lot of you guys made,” Mr. Obama said afterward. “The difference is they did not have the kinds of support structures, the second chances, the resources that would allow them to survive those mistakes.”

>He added that “we have a tendency sometimes to almost take for granted or think it’s normal” that so many young people have been locked up. “It’s not normal,” he said. “It’s not what happens in other countries. What is normal is teenagers doing stupid things. What is normal is young people making mistakes.”

>Mr. Obama had the benefit of a largely comfortable upbringing and attended a premier Honolulu prep school before going on to Ivy League universities. If those now in prison for drug crimes had those advantages, he said, they “could be thriving the way we are.”

The *Times* notes that the issue of revamping the federal prison system and mandatory minimum sentencing has become a bipartisan issue in the last few years, a “once politically unthinkable” phenomenon that will soon come up for debate in Congress.

items.hed: *Ant-Man* Director Peyton Reed on the Film‘s Most Impressive Effect . . . and the Backup Plan
items.dek: Plus, when he got permission to make a Marvel movie that made fun of superheroes.
items.body:
The most spectacular sight in *Ant-Man* comes at the very beginning. An official-looking meeting in a big expansive room, filled with faces we’ve seen from other Marvel movies, is suddenly joined by what must be a ghost. It’s __Michael Douglas__, but not the goateed, 70-year-old Michael Douglas cast in Ant-Man. It’s Michael Douglas from the post–*Wall Street*, pre–*The Game* era. It’s impossible. It’s kind of head-spinning.

And it could have not happened at all. To de-age Douglas 30 years for an opening scene set in the late 80s, the *Ant-Man* production team enlisted Lola VFX, the same company that [magically shrunk __Chris Evans__]( http://www.fxguide.com/featured/case-study-how-to-make-a-captain-america-wimp/) in the early scenes of *Captain America: The First Avenger.* The team had already proven they could do stunning work, but director __Peyton Reed__ admits there was a backup plan, too. Douglas, his goatee shaved and motion-tracking dots all over his face, was on set to film the scenes, but there was also a body double who looked convincingly like a late-80s Douglas. “It was absolutely a safety,” Reed admits.  “I was incredibly nervous. If that effect didn’t come off, it’s the first scene in the movie . . .”

Hard as it was to convince the *Captain America* audience that the beefy actor seen in the trailers started as a 140-pound wimp, de-aging Michael Douglas didn’t just require trickery, but a kind of mental time travel. “Everybody knows what Michael Douglas looked like 25 years ago,” Reed says. That meant that specific details had to be included, not just from Douglas but the double, too. “It was always at least going to be some blend of Michael Douglas and this look-alike actor,” Reed continues. “From my standpoint, we wanted to gather as much material for Lola to have at their disposal to create this effect.”

The *Ant-Man* team wasn’t exactly lacking for challenges even before the de-aged Douglas idea came up. Director __Edgar Wright__ left the project last May, after spending years developing it, and Reed stepped in just months before filming began, with star __Paul Rudd__ and writer/director __Adam McKay__ still at work polishing the script. Reed, whose previous film was the __Jim Carrey__ comedy *Yes Man* and who also directed the throwback rom-com *Down with Love*, seemed about as far from the fanboy-beloved Wright as you could get.  


[#image: /photos/55a8288c9e9755183d9738b0]|||
Rudd as Scott Lang, a little skeptical about the Ant-Man suit. 
|||





Wright and his collaborator, __Joe Cornish__, are still credited for the film’s story, and critics have made a guessing game of spotting where Wright’s fingerprints still remain. But some of *Ant-Man*’s best moments—a fight-scene cameo from Anthony Mackie’s Falcon, a series of hilariously rambling montages narrated by __Michael Peña’s__ petty crook, a trippy visit to the “quantum realm”—are Reed’s. The director who spent years developing a *Fantastic Four* movie and was a runner-up for *Guardians of the Galaxy* was a long time getting to his superhero movie, and though hewing in many ways to the [Marvel house style](https://thedissolve.com/features/the-conversation/265-what-marvels-shared-universe-means-for-movies/), Reed has made it his own. 

And that includes making fun of the movie’s entire existence, starting with its leading man. “The Ant-Man powers are pretty absurd,” says Reed, who has compared the initial skeptical reactions to *Ant-Man* to what he heard when making *Bring It On*, a fluffy cheerleader movie now revered as a minor classic. “It’s important to have Rudd at the center of [the film] because he reacts the way the audience does.” Namely, with befuddlement: early trailers show Rudd’s Scott Lang being presented with the name “Ant-Man” and asking, [“Is it too late to change the name?”](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ol5qWkUJeEA) 

That ability to poke fun at superhero tropes has been present in Marvel’s zippy films since the first *Iron Man*, but last summer’s *Guardians of the Galaxy*—[“What a bunch of A-holes”](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B16Bo47KS2g)—brought the self-mockery to a new level. *Ant-Man* was well underway by the time *Guardians* became a hit, but its success still paved that road much more for Reed’s own tongue-in-cheek take on a superhero origin story. “I have to imagine that guardians gave Marvel some confidence that they could do some weird stuff and people would still show up,” he says, while insisting, “I think I was always instilled with that feeling from Kevin Feige from the beginning. The worst mistake you can make with Marvel is [to] repeat yourself.”

Coming from a guy who’s done a cheerleader comedy, a 60s sex farce, and now a Marvel movie, that’s pretty convincing advice.
items.seoDescription: Plus, when director Peyton Reed got permission to make a Marvel movie that made fun of superheroes.
items.socialTitle: How Ant-Man De-Aged Michael Douglas, and Why They Had a Backup Plan
items.socialDescription: Plus, when director Peyton Reed got permission to make a Marvel movie that made fun of superheroes.

items.hed: Uber Takes Its War on New York City to Another Level
items.dek: It’s a full-blown “hearts and minds” campaign.
items.body:
New York City is now the latest battleground between government and Uber, the car-hailing app that’s become a luxury for millions of city-dwellers, a source of contractual employment for thousands of drivers, and a nuisance for Mayor Bill de Blasio and the city’s taxi lobby.
 
In response to what the city claims is a massive traffic problem for the city—the number of cars available for hire in New York has grown by a staggering 60 percent since 2011, [according to the *New York Times*](http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/17/nyregion/city-hall-and-uber-clash-in-struggle-over-new-york-streets.html?_r=0)—the City Council will soon vote on whether to place a cap on the number of drivers Uber can employ in New York City. Naturally, Uber is unhappy that the city wants to halt their growth, especially given their growing consumer base. 
 
While it hasn’t gotten as bad as, say, Paris (where taxi drivers began [lighting things on fire](http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/26/europe/france-paris-uberpop-protests/) in protest of the company’s UberPOP service), the N.Y.C. battle has begun to ramp up in so many other ways. Via the *Times:*
 
>The company has aired television advertisements, starring Uber drivers, that portray Mr. de Blasio as an enemy to working residents, and flooded Council districts with mailers denouncing members who support the cap.
 
>[A top Uber operative], __David Plouffe__, the former campaign manager for President Obama, has been dispatched to New York City for a round of appearances and meetings, including an audience with the mayor himself at City Hall earlier this week. . . . 
 
> And in a touch of stagecraft intended to highlight [the company’s working-class minority employees] Mr. Plouffe visited Harlem on Tuesday, appearing at Sylvia’s, the landmark soul food restaurant in Harlem, joined by more than a dozen community leaders, all of them black, and all of them critical of the proposed cap.
 
Perhaps the snidest move Uber’s pulled so far? A “de Blasio” button on the app’s homepage, that will reveal how long the wait will be for an Uber in a world where de Blasio’s evil car dictatorship exists:
 


[#image: /photos/55a7ee38fff2c16856a6ce55]||||||





 
(Whenever VF.com opened the app from Lower Manhattan, the de Blasio version always registered a 25-minute wait.)
 
Granted, Uber’s problems in New York aren’t as dramatic as they are in other cities: along with France, several other European countries, including [Germany](http://www.bbc.com/news/technology-31942997) and[Italy]( http://www.wsj.com/articles/uber-ordered-to-discontinue-uberpop-service-in-italy-1432654165), have outright banned Uber for breaking transport laws. (Those angry French taxi drivers successfully got UberPOP banned from France.) 
 
And in a blow to the company’s future prospects, a San Francisco judge ruled Wednesday that by refusing to give data on whether their employees purposely did not serve customers based on race or disabilities, Uber violated discrimination laws. The court [recommended](http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-uber-suspended-20150715-story.html) that the company be suspended from operation in its own home state of California. Wednesday’s verdict comes on the heels of another loss, in which the California Labor Commission [ruled](http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/06/18/us-uber-california-idUSKBN0OX1TE20150618) that Uber’s drivers qualified as employees, not contractors—a key part of the company’s model.
items.seoTitle: Uber Takes Its War on New York City to Another Level
items.seoDescription: It’s a full-blown “hearts and minds” campaign.
items.socialTitle: Uber Takes Its War on New York City to Another Level
items.socialDescription: It’s a full-blown “hearts and minds” campaign.
